verses.text: Lord, do not rebuke me in your anger, nor discipline me in your wrath.
verses.comment: The psalmist opens with a plea to God for mercy, paralleling Psalm 6:1. This reveals the heart's awareness of God's justice and a longing for gentle correction, a balance in the spiritual life.

verses.text: For your arrows have sunk into me, and your hand has come down upon me.
verses.comment: God's discipline is pictured as arrows and a heavy hand, signifying both conviction of sin and the pain of conscience. Many saints have described this sense of God's presence leading to repentance.

verses.text: There is no soundness in my flesh because of your anger; there is no health in my bones because of my sin.
verses.comment: Sin affects both soul and body, which is a consistent biblical theme. The connection between spiritual health and physical well-being is underscored, preparing for the later Christian doctrine of the resurrection of the body (see 1 Cor. 15:42-44).

verses.text: For my iniquities have gone over my head; like a heavy burden, they are too heavy for me to bear.
verses.comment: The psalmist confesses personal sinfulness, echoing the need for confession and recognizing human limitations. This prefigures the Christian practice of confessing sins and receiving forgiveness by God's mercy (see 1 John 1:9).

verses.text: My wounds are foul and festering because of my foolishness.
verses.comment: Sin is seen as not just moral error but spiritual sickness that festers. This theme is foundational for the biblical teaching of sin as an illness needing both healing and forgiveness (see Matt. 9:12-13).

verses.text: I am bent over, I am bowed down greatly; I go mourning all day long.
verses.comment: Bodily posture reflects deep inner grief and repentance, anticipating the later use of bodily expressions like kneeling in liturgical worship and penitence.

verses.text: For my sides are filled with burning, and there is no health in my body.
verses.comment: Pain and sickness are directly connected in the psalm to a spiritual cause, underlining the truth that soul and body are not separate in Hebrew thought.

verses.text: I am feeble and utterly crushed; I groan because of the anguish of my heart.
verses.comment: A powerful depiction of the misery caused by sin and God's discipline. The inner groaning anticipates the Christian reality that the Spirit intercedes for us with groans too deep for words (see Rom. 8:26).

verses.text: Lord, all my desire is before you, and my sighing is not hidden from you.
verses.comment: The psalmist acknowledges God's perfect knowledge of the heart—a theme deepened by Christ's teaching about God's intimacy and personal care for each believer (see Matt. 6:8).

verses.text: My heart throbs, my strength fails me; even the light of my eyes—it has also gone from me.
verses.comment: The effect of sin and suffering reaches deep—heart, body, and even perception. Early interpreters see here a foreshadowing of Jesus’ agony in Gethsemane.

verses.text: My loved ones and my friends stand aloof from my plague; my relatives stand far off.
verses.comment: Isolation is part of the suffering that comes with sin and illness. This separation anticipates Christ’s experience of abandonment by his disciples (see Matt. 26:56).

verses.text: Those who seek my life lay snares; those who seek my harm speak of destruction and plot treachery all day long.
verses.comment: David’s enemies plot against him, an image used in the Gospels for the plotting of the enemies of Christ. The typology connects David’s suffering with Christ’s.

verses.text: But I, like a deaf man, do not hear; and like a mute man who does not open his mouth.
verses.comment: The silence in the face of suffering is reminiscent of Isaiah’s prophecy of the Suffering Servant (Isa. 53:7), fulfilled in Christ, who was silent before his accusers (Matt. 27:12-14).

verses.text: Yes, I am like a man who does not hear, and whose mouth offers no reply.
verses.comment: Maintaining silence amidst slander and suffering reflects a posture of trust in God’s justice—a trait perfectly exemplified in Christ’s Passion.

verses.text: For in you, O Lord, I hope; you will answer, O Lord my God.
verses.comment: Faith in God’s ultimate deliverance anchors the soul in the midst of suffering. Hope and trust in divine response remain at the center of biblical faith.

verses.text: For I said, 'Lest they rejoice over me—when my foot slips, they magnify themselves against me.'
verses.comment: The psalmist appeals to God’s vindication, anxious that his enemies not take credit for his downfall. This reflects a yearning for God’s justice in the face of injustice.

verses.text: For I am ready to fall; and my pain is ever before me.
verses.comment: Ongoing awareness of one’s weakness and pain leads to genuine humility, a core biblical virtue that disposes the heart toward God’s mercy and healing.

verses.text: I confess my iniquity; I am troubled because of my sin.
verses.comment: The act of confession and interior contrition is essential for true forgiveness, as later illustrated in the New Testament (James 5:16; 1 John 1:9). The psalmist’s model points to continual confession as a path to reconciliation.

verses.text: But my enemies are vigorous and strong; those who hate me without cause are many.
verses.comment: Hated without cause—a phrase echoed in John 15:25 regarding Christ. The righteous sufferer foreshadows the trials Christ and his followers would face.

verses.text: Those who repay evil for good accuse me, because I follow what is good.
verses.comment: Unjust opposition to the righteous is a recurring theme. Jesus’ life and teaching about blessing those who persecute us (Matt. 5:44) embody this ideal.

verses.text: Do not forsake me, O Lord; my God, do not be far from me.
verses.comment: A plea for God’s nearness calls to mind Jesus’ own prayer from the cross (Ps. 22:1) and the assurance that God never abandons those who seek Him (Heb. 13:5).

verses.text: Make haste to help me, O Lord, my salvation!
verses.comment: The closing cry for deliverance prefigures Christ as Savior and the need for prompt aid in time of trial. The Psalm as a whole is both a penitential prayer and a prophecy fulfilled in the suffering, patient Messiah.
